name.value: L'Aube des Morts-Vivants: Bataille sur Farmingdale

item.description:
THE BATTLE FOR FARMINGDALE

States of SiegeTM #9

Voted #1 on The Gaming Gang's Top 10 Games of 2011!

Like a deathly hand from the grave comes Dawn of the Zeds, a States of Siege solitaire game of horror and survival from designer Hermann Luttmann .
The world has gone crazy – a deadly virus has turned ordinary people into vicious, zombie-like killers. The undead, nicknamed "Zeds," are now converging on your corner of the world. You have been left to your own devices to stop them while the National Guard organizes a relief column and fights its way to you – but that could take days, or even weeks, before they arrive.

At the town of Farmingdale and its surrounding villages, you must coordinate its defenses. Regular citizens may emerge as heroes as you work to halt the Zeds' advances by (re)killing them, discovering and implementing a cure to this vile scourge, and preserving the area and its inhabitants as much as possible.

In a game that requires the utmost test of skill and nerve, will you survive long enough? Will you be able to fight hordes of Zeds while protecting the townspeople? Unearth the possibilities with Dawn of the Zeds, a nightmare that ends with your fate ranging between being a hero or a hero sandwich .




L'Aube des Morts-Vivants, un jeu en solitaire d'horreur et de survie de la série "State of Siege"TM conçu par Hermann Luttmann, surgi comme une main sortant de la tombe.

Le monde est devenu fou, un virus mortel a transformé les gens ordinaires en zombies tueurs et vicieux. Ces Morts-Vivants surnommés Zeds, convergent maintenant vers votre petit coin de paradis ! Vous avez été laissé à vous-même pour les arrêter et préserver votre communauté alors qu'une colonne de secours de la Garde Nationale se bat pour vous rejoindre ; mais cela pourra prendre des jours, voire des semaines, avant qu'ils n'arrivent. Vous devez prendre la tête de vos administrés assiégés !

Des citoyens ordinaires deviennent des héros alors que vous oeuvrez pour arrêter l'avancée des Zeds en les (re)tuant, en découvrant et administrant un remède à cette terrible épidémie afin de préserver votre secteur et ses habitants autant que possible.

Dans un jeu qui requiert un sang-froid et des nerfs à toute épreuve, survivrez-vous assez longtemps ?
Serez-vous capable de combattre les hordes de Zeds tout en protégeant votre population ?
Découvrez toutes les possibilités de l'Aube des Morts-Vivants, un cauchemar qui déterminera si votre destin est de devenir un héros ou de terminer en casse-dalle !

link.value: Victory Point Games States of Siege Series

item.description:
In 1836, Americans, who since the early 1800s had been migrating and settling in the Mexican territory of Texas, along with the Mexican locals (Tejanos), were attempting to establish an independent republic. Seized early in the revolt against Mexican authority by these Texians (as these American-led revolutionaries were called), the Alamo Mission in San Antonio was surrounded and besieged by the forces of His Excellency, Don Antonio Lopez de Santa Anna.

The Alamo Remembered is a quick, 1-2 player, historical game covering those dramatic minutes when legends were made at the Alamo. In this game of bluff and counter-bluff, command the Texian or Mexican units, defending or attacking the walls of the Alamo.

With no dice rolling, rules to cover many variable conditions during this historic assault, and a “Last Stand” climax to the game, the birth of Texas is yours to relive. As the Texians, can you hold out at the Alamo to the last, or as the Mexicans quickly breach walls for glory? Find out in The Alamo Remembered!

Game Data:

Complexity: 2 on a 9 scale
Solitaire Suitability: 7 on a 9 scale
Scale: Each unit represents 25-30 men, or 1 artillery unit. Each turn represents 10 minutes of real time.

Polybag Game Components:

• One beautiful 8.5" x 16.5" game map
• 54 double-sided 3/4" square game pieces
• 16-page full color Rules booklet (Optional and Solitaire rules included!)

What's In The Box?:

• One beautiful 8.5" x 16.5" game map
• 54 double-sided 3/4" square game pieces
• 16-page full color Rules booklet (Optional and Solitaire rules included!)
• One 8.5" x 16.5" mounted, jigsaw-cut game map
• One bright red, 9 1/4" x 5 7/8" Standard cardboard VPG game box
• One beautiful box cover sleeve
• One "Wipes-A-Lot" napkin
• One charcoal dessicant packet

item.description:
"Canadian Prime Minister, Stephen Harper, in agreement with Russia, warned USA to “keep their hands off the Arctic.”

Despite the cover picture "2019: The Arctic" is an economic game, however some military aspect is also included. In the game, players manage mineral resource companies interested in exploration of the Arctic region. They aim to maximize their scores, expressed in points, by undertaking actions that give them specific benefits or weaken the position of competitors.

The path to gain advantage over the competition is on one hand the investment policy that will provide a variety of resources, and on the other - controlling a large quantity of deposits of the same type, which will allow to dominate in a given segment of raw materials industry.

The tool for achieving the goal and winning the game is shaping the internal and foreign policy of the Arctic region countries (Russia, Norway, the European Union, Canada, USA). In addition to that, China’s participation in the race for access to the Arctic resources is simulated in the game.

Players may use their political powers to obtain subsidies from a given country’s budget and to secure their investments in mining platforms built on the sea behind the scenes. However, the main axis of the gameplay is exerting direct influence upon the policies of the countries by a wide range of political and economical actions taken on their behalf.

STRONG NEGATIVE INTERACTION and NO LUCK FACTOR

To be released at Essen 2011

item.description: Alphabet Rummy consists of a deck of 65 cards each displaying a letter of the alphabet and a point value. The idea is to score points by creating words using the cards you are dealt. Players can create new words or add onto other players'.

Car Racing game derived from the original Monza Boardgame

Create a track by placing the track cards on the table. Each player places a car on start.
Some parts of the track have oil stains that cannot be entered.

During the game you will play traffic Light cards. The cards show a traffic light containing 3 different colors (some of them even have a rainbow light)

2 variants to play:
Basic: Draw a "traffic light card", play it and move your car.
Pro" Every player takes 3 cards in his hand, and chooses which one to play, after play you take another card

The dungeon goes through the ground.
It's also very famous in the world as the treasure"God bless". Anybody said the "God bless" was placed on the most deep floor, and any monsters lived in the dungeon. It's many and many.

However, in this world, the monsters live anywhere without cities and towns. The people sometimes has a battle with them. But the monsters in the dungeon are different with other monsters. Because anyone can't see the "God bless".

So the people was interested in "God bless" and the dungeon. At first, it's mercenaries and ventures. But a few years ago, the nobles are interested in them.
The nobles hire the mercenaries and ventures and so on, and they pay the cost to the mercenaries and ventures, they take any treasure in the dungeon. Of course, their target is "God bless".

The player is one of the nobles. They hire the mercenaries and ventures and so on, and take the any treasure and a honor as stars. The stars means the noble can go to more deep floor. It's a honor to other nobles.

The player with most stars is a winner.

link.value: Ore no Shikabane wo Koeteyuke -Jigoku Meguri-

item.description:
Girls' 20 Questions is the first game for girls that gives them the credit they deserve for being smart. Girls love it because it's fast and exciting;
Each round round features a new mystery identity - a person, place or thing that appeals to girls. As players listen to a seriesof clues, each clue reveals more about the mystery identity. The trick is to solve the identity in the fewest clues - the fewer clues needed, the farther players advance.
Travel version of this popular classic board game including only 52 cards. Players ask up to 20 Questions to guess the Person, Place or Thing.

119 cards + a rules card.

Card game, intended to break the ice at a party. Each party-goer is given a number of cards, say, 4 blue, 4 red and 4 green. How many cards is decided by the host and his or her decision will be made after seeing how many party-goers there are.
Each player walks around chatting to the party-goers and tries to find two cards that 'go' with the card she or he already has. You need to trade your card with another, to make a set of three. In case you can't remember what to do, the cards are in three colours (and you need one of each to complete your set), and they are numbered 1, 2 or 3 (you need one of each to make a sentence. The sentence starts with the blue card text, then the red card text and, finally, the green card text. The sillier the sentence, the more chance you have of winning.

Once you have one sentence of nonsense, then you start collecting another sentence. At some point during the party, an end to the game is called and the collected sentences are read out. The winner is the one who colloected the most absurd sentence (in a show of hands by the party-goers.

The title means 'Never laughed so much' and the box says 'For adults; An Advertising Salad - Well seasoned'.

item.description:
Mutt-Opoly is a mutt-themed version of the game Monopoly, "celebrating the world's most popular dog."

In this roll-and-move property trading game, properties are individual mutts that can be traded between players. Properties also include themed locations such as a fire hydrant and butcher shop. Other themed features of the game are Dog Toys (rather than houses) and Big Bones (rather than hotels), "Good Dog" and "Bad Dog" cards, and the Kennel, where a player may end up out of the game for three turns.

Players pay money when they land on each other's properties, and the goal is to bankrupt your opponents.

link.value: Late for the Sky Production Company

item.description:
This roll-and-move game has the elements of a traditional real estate trading game with a wild animal theme.

Instead of buying real estate, players become caretakers of animals. When they land on another player's animal, they must pay meal fees. Rather than building houses (as in standard Monopoly), players collect land, water, food and clean air, then may trade them in for a habitat where an animal can survive on its own. Also, the back of each animal card contains several facts about the relevant animal; cards that players draw are either "Jungle Fun" or "Get Wild!" The "Hiding" space takes a player out of play for three turns, while "Explore" is the Go space in standard Monopoly.

The goal of the game is to bankrupt the other players.

link.value: Late for the Sky Production Company

item.description:
Cycle-Opoly is a property trading game with a bike theme.

Players use cycling tokens, start at "PEDAL!," and buy favorite bikes, accessories, and bike rides across the country. Players increase their property value by collecting Rides and Big Fun. Draw cards are "Bike Lane" or "Share the Road," and players can be sidelined for three turns in the "Flat Tire" space. The back side of property cards contain facts about different types of bikes, some of the country’s most well known rides and races, and cycling trivia. The goal of the game is to bankrupt the other riders.

link.value: Late for the Sky Production Company

item.description:
In this 1 on 1 fighting game, each player controls a "karate fighter" using a spinning dial that makes the fighter throw kicks and punches. The object is to kick your opponent in the chest hard enough to make him fly off the base. The electronic version would let out a blood-curdling scream when a fighter would fly off. Considered to be the "Rock'em Sock'em robots" of the 90's, Karate Fighters took the fighting genre to a new level. Imagine the video game "Mortal Kombat" brought to life.

Several Editions were released:
Red Ninja Vs. Dragon Kick
Samurai Ninja Vs. Headstone - Electronic
Tiger Ninja Vs. Cyberfist - Electronic
Razorjaw Vs. Sun Warrior
Serpent Strike Vs. The Iron Claw
Thunderfoot Vs. Skull Crusher
Kick Star Vs. Corporal Punishment

Other Playable Ninjas Sold Separately via Mail in Offer:
The Dark Ninja
Silver Sword

4 Player Combat Arena
Rex Havoc Vs. The Tattoo Terror

Alternate Editions:
Batman Vs. The Joker
GI:Joe: Duke Vs. Neo Viper
Transformers: Optimus Prime Vs. Megatron
Small Soldiers: Chip Hazard Vs. Archer

A set collection game with some of the finest card illustrations. 72 cards making 24 pictures cut into three parts.
Each player is given 12 counters. Everyone now puts 5 counters into the 'Pool' and receives cards, leaving half the pack as a 'reserve'.
The player sitting left of the dealer starts and must play the first card of any set, if he has one. The next player plays a second card to the set started by the player to his right, if he has such a card. And so on, until a full set of three cards is revealed. The player playing the third part of the set (actually, called a trick in the rules), and must now start a new set if he can. There are penalties for a player not playing a card when he should or if the wrong picture is completed and so on. If you genuinely cannot play a card, you draw a card from the reserve.
Interestingly, for a game of this age, you can score bonus points for certain tricks or negative bonuses for some tricks.
For example, completing the Baby set takes 5 counters from the pool and one counter from every other player, or completing the Horse Omnibus set pays three counters into the pool, and so on.
The player taking the most tricks when all 24 sets have been completed takes the remaining counters in the pool and the player now with the most counters, wins the game.

52 cards in sets of four, each depicting a face that is revealing a certain look; smiling, frowning, angry, etc.
I don't have the rules so I don't know more details. The cards are beautifully illustrated. Could be a Snap type game (although the cards would not suit a children's game). I would think it had more adult appeal.

Cubex consists of 9 cubes, with each side representing a playing card, so you get 54 sides (1 deck + 2 jokers).
The play is rather interesting. First you take the cubes out of the box, then, in turn order, each player selects a cube and places it back into the box. Once all 9 cubes are back in the box, the second phase begins. The starting player takes any cube from the four corners and starts to form a 3 x 3 wall of 'bricks'. The next selected cube must be taken from the space adjacent to the first cube, in clockwise order. Remember, when you choose a cube and place it, the opposite side of the cube will be facing your opponent, so you need to help yourself whilst also giving non-attractive 'cards' to your opponent.
The main game is one where you try to get the best Brag (a form of Poker but only three cards count) hand facing you. There are other games suggested, with a form of Patience being the best.

A Monopoly type game (roll the dice, move round the board, but this game is set in the world of football.
Contents - the box says 'This box contains one playing board and approximately 450 components'.
Each player has the objective to take his team from the 3rd Division to the 1st Division and then to win the title. There are numerous cards such as, Press Report, Disciplinary Hearing, Result, that sort of thing.
The idea is to buy players who are good in the Division you are currently in, and improve the team's performance. The track on board is octagonal and six sides relate to week-days and two sides relate to Saturday morning and afternoon. On that afternoon you collect gate receipts when you pass the square designated for that purpose. This improves as you rise up the divisions. Also in this section, you can choose to earn 1 point for your match (the game was a draw) or you can purchase a Result card and take your chances.
The designers were two British footballers, quite well-known.

link.value: David Nish and Roger Davies Productions

item.description:
Swish is a pattern recognition card game reminiscent of Set that challenges a player to make matches – dubbed "Swishes" – before opponents.

Swish includes 60 transparent cards; each card has some combination of balls and hoops on it, with these items coming in four colors. To set up the game, lay out 16 cards on the table. Players simultaneously try to create "Swishes" by spotting two or more cards that can be laid on top of one another in some manner so that every ball fits in a hoop of the same color. Create a Swish, and you claim the cards used, with new cards then being laid out. Whoever claims the most cards wins the game.

The game includes varied levels of play so that the spatially clueless can compete against Tetris-heads.

item.description:
Fun game for children. The box holds a number of plastic tracks that link together. They can be used in many different configurations.
Each child gets a plastic 'Mexican Jumping Bean'. They place their bean in the starting gate, and the gate is opened. First down the course is the winner. No skill, just amusement.

The goal of Snuffy Race is for players to propel their dog along the winding path, using a small plastic bellows against the dog’s fan-shaped tail, right into the bowl in the center which contains dog bones.

As soon as a dog has reached the bowl, that player collects a bone, moves their dog back to the start of their path, and sets off again to get another bone.

If the dog falls over or falls off the path, then it must be returned to the start of the path.

The player whose dog retrieves the most bones is the winner.

A magazine that comes with collectible trading cards themed mostly on the new Doctor Who adventures, with some special cards recalling the earlier TV series. Each issue of DWMI contains a new game using the cards, which have a range of stats unique to that card. The first issue contains the games, Stat Attack, Survivor and Alien Attack, and playmats for the games.
Stat Attack is a straight comparison of stats, like Top Trumps.
The second issue introduces the game UNIT Challenge, where you can combine stats on your cards to get a higher rating.

An educational game featuring the building of the railways across North America in the 19th century.
The board is overlayed with a square grid and each square has a number in it (from 2 to 10) and this is the cost of building a railway through that square. Railways are drawn on the board as they are built (similar to Railway Rivals).
Two packs of Chance Cards, but these are way too lucky or unlucky. One pack is used until someone reaches the Rocky Mountains and then the 2nd stack is used "More in keeping with the 2nd phase of the game" say the rules.
The Railway Pioneer with the most money after a set time, wins.

Rallytaire is a paper and pencil rally game for one player. You have to plan ahead and adapt to the track and sometimes push your luck a bit. It has mechanics similar to Formula D but using only six sided dice and corners are also handled differently.

Players choose which gear to drive in, roll a few 6 sided dice and move according to those rolls. Then they write their position on the track with the goal of getting as fast as possible through it. Players can push their cars to the limit trying to win some time and between stages it's possible to fix the car so it will be ready for the next track.

Drift through those corners and beat the tracks record!

item.description:
In Yoga-Yingo players preform different Yoga poses to fill up a BINGO style card.The cards contain a 3x3 grid of photos of yoga poses. Players assume and hold the pose to cover the space. First to cover three in a row wins.

Product Features

Pictures demonstrating each yoga pose and modifications
 Instructions include Sanskrit names for kids who would like to learn more
 Instructions include modifications to increase/decrease challenges
 Contains 12 game board cards.
 Non-competitive play. Gross motor play and development

includes 12 game cards, 8 pose cards, 120 markers,and a Yoga pose instruction sheet.

name.value: Dice Age Alpha Edition: Fundamental series

item.description:
Unbalanced, designer's toy dice. They can be used in different specific games, of skill (totem game), of strategy (the War of the Lords), of risk-taking (The Crown of Lords), as divination device or as dominoes... Our players come up with new games and rules all the time.

Components: Dice (24 different dice in the Fundamental series), Dice Pouch.
Unique Game Aspect: Unbalanced and artistic handmade dice that can be played in different ways.

link.value: Dice Age Alpha Edition: Blue Tide series

item.description:
"Crazy Bugs" is a card game that shows how bugs, worms, and other insects support a healthy environment. A cross between "Crazy Eights" and "Trivial Pursuit," "Crazy Bugs" teaches children how, in some countries, insects serve as a main food source; and how insects generate things like honey, wax, and dyes.

The object of the game is to get rid of all your "Deal Me In" Cards by answering questions about insect life and the environment and win!

Contents: 

 52 Deal Me In Cards, 
 2 Wild Bug Cards, 
 45 Bug Fact Cards,

Did you know the constellations are grouped by astronomers into families - like the Hercules, Heavenly Waters and Ursa Major families - whose members are in the same region of the night sky?

Constellation Connect! is a stellar variation of Go Fish Children explore the stars and collect star points while learning major regions of the night sky. Special cards like Comet Sighting, Northern Lights and Meteor Shower and also a galactic die to change the game play up in lots of spacey ways.throw fun and crazy twists into the game play. An included subject guide teaches about the many multicultural mythologies tied to the constellations.

Players take turns building a crossword puzzle in the provided grid using a hand of random clues and a hand of letter tiles. Clues come in five types:
Same or Opposite: the solution is a synonym or antonym of the clue word.
Crossword Clue: the solution word and the clue word are broadly related, perhaps in a punning way.
A Word Including: the solution word contains the clue word.
Clue It Yourself: the solution word may be any word, provided the player provides a suitable clue.
Found With: the solution word and the clue word are found together in some phrase.
Words are scored at a simple one point per letter.

name.value: Monopoly: The Lord of the Rings Collectors Edition

item.description: This game is different and uniqe from the Lord of the Rings Monopoly, Trilogy edition. This one has different pieces, the board art is unique. The box size is the same as most other collectable versions of Monopoly. This version comes with the following pewter tokens: The sword Sting, Aragorn's Crown, an Elven Broach, Boromir's Gondorian Horn, Gandalf's Hat, and Bill the Pony.

Each player is running their own vineyard. You are attempting to grow grapes and sell them to increase your wealth and also undertake research to improve your knowledge so that you are able to grow each grape harvest more efficiently.

The game is card based and during each turn you typically play a card from your hand and then draw another card from the draw pile.

The game goes over a number of rounds. Each round is ended when one of the players undertakes a grape harvest. The person who harvests is able to gain wealth while their opponent has the potential to improve their knowledge.

The winner is the first person to either 12 points of wealth (with at least 4 points of knowledge) or 6 points of knowledge (with at least 5 points of wealth).

item.description: A small trivia game about barbecuing; with 100 questions and answers. The game itself is like a notebook (with spiral binding). Each page contains 2 questions and 4 possible answers, the back side contains the correct answers with additional information.

A simple roll-and-move game but with an added feature, you may be instructed to move in or out of the orbit you are currently in. The first to reach Mars (after starting at Earth) wins. Should you be unlucky enough to fall into the Sun, you are out of the game.

The game is featured in Victorian Board Games by Olivia Bristol.

Another version produced by Glevum has similar game plan but updated graphics from around the 1920s

A custom-made version of the Geni Pocket game (http://www.boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/69152/pocket-geni-classic) made to the 200th years anniversary of University of Oslo (UiO) in 2011.

The game contains 450 Q&As about UiO, in six categories; UiO, studies and student life, science and medicin, history and society, culture and language, mixed.

name.value: All About Ithaca & Tompkins County, NY

item.description:
"An exciting, fast moving game of travel" - from box.

The object of the game is for players to travel on the gameboard to the locations shown on their shopping lists. The first player to return to their residence with the travel cards for all locations contained on their shopping list wins the game!

Players start with $2000 and get 10x the dice roll in money when they visit the bank initially (which has to be done first). To get the travel cards, players need to pay 10x the dice roll on the turn that they visit that location. Players can visit the bank later in the game, but not until they run out of money. Players get 10x their die roll and need to pay back what they owe with 10% interest. Players can choose to stay at the bank and roll for one additional turn and collect 10x what their roll is.

name.value: Raiding Parties: Golden Age of Piracy

item.description: Raiding Parties is a pirate themed deck-building game in which you are the commander who selects a crew to hire as part of your Raiding Party, and then players will test their fate on the battlefield! All of the artwork has been created by Don Maitz (the creator of the Captain Morgan Spiced Rum Logo) including the card template and the game logo. This is a fast paced game of pirate battles where each card has weapons and abilities that "hit" on certain flips from a separate deck of 52 playing cards.

link.value: Raiding Parties: Brethren Of The Coast

name.value: Jr. Rangerland National Parks Board Game

item.description:
Grab your binoculars and visit our National Parks. In this game of color matching and exploration, players collect Explorer Cards as they journey to National parks throughout the United States. They will experience many landmarks, buildings, and natural wonders while always on the lookout for plants, animals, items of interest and opportunities to care for the parks.

The Explorer Cards include many plants, animals, and geological features. There are also cards that provide opportunities for players to help out around the park or discover some important historical or cultural facts. There are 32 cards in all!

The winner of the game is the person who can gather the most Explorer cards.

As an extra challenge, players can look for matching plants and animals that show up on the Explorer cards. They are hidden on the game board.

No reading is required.

Del Editor:

En un reino de maldad, un grupo de súpervillanos peleará entre si, codo a codo para destruir al mundo.

Porque lo único que podría detener a un súpervillano, es la envidia de otro súpervillano!

¡Divertido juego en el que podrás demostrar si es mejor ganar o hacer perder a los demás!"

From the Publisher:

In an evil kingdom a group of supervillains fight each other side by side to destroy the world.

The olnly thing that could stop a supervillain is the envy of other supervillains!!

Fun game where you can show whether it is better to win or make lose each other!

Each player represents a supervillain trying to build a machine to destroy the world. You collect the parts of the machine (represented by cards) and complete it before a rival destroy all your progress. There are several ways (cards) to destroy the progress of a player such as "Sabotage" and "theft " also we have defenses to each of these cards as "immunity " or "divine justice"

The sequence in which you build your machine is:

- 1 machine layout
 - 1 Power Supply
 - 3 different components
 - 1 special component
 - 4 final count cards (... 3 ... 2 ... 1 ... KABOOM)

The first player to blow up his or her machine is the winner.

item.description:
A game of frantic energy as you grow a small startup courier business to become the best in the city.

The game is for 2-4 players aged 10+.

Players assume the role of CEO of a small courier company, each company can be setup in different ways so that players can maximize the differences they have with other players and exploit different business styles.

Players must quickly collect parcels in a turn that uses simultaneous play, a game for the quick of mind and quick of hand. The more successful you become the quicker you will need to become in seeing opportunity and taking it.

Balance this out with a few moments to plan and purchase ways to grow your business with improvements or expansions, building you business through various growth stages, each stage offering more choices and options to make you business more efficient and profitable.

To be released mid-2011.

From the back of the box:

"A game of buying and selling
Banking
Mortgaging
etc."

A little later...

"International Business is well known worldwide with different names. This is an evergreen game where you act as a foreign businessman who buy or sell properties in famous countries of world. You also get an idea to deal with another person. So, let play & ready to prove himself, the wealthiest person of the world."

Poor grammar is from the back of the box.

The game itself has a lot ripped off from Monopoly with only some minor changes and totally different subject matter.

item.description: This is an obscure Trivia game that tests you knowledge about topics from Kwanzaa to Egyptian history. It gives a very narrow slice of what the author thought people should know with a slant towards African, Egyptian, and African-American history.

name.value: Shamu and his Crew, Protect Our Seas Game

item.description:
From the back of the box:

"Go on an ocean voyage with Shamu and his friends!

Get ready for a spectacular journey where you will help brng Shamu's friends to safety! In this exciting game, you'll have fun as you learn about some of the dangers that face our friends who live in the seas. Dolly Dolphin is caught in a net and Pete Penguin is atop an iceberg. Baby Shamu has been beached and O.P. Otter us in an oil slick. But help is on the way!

Roll the die and send your Shamu mover across the ocean floor to the danger spaces. Once you get there, you'll be able to resuce Shamu's friends. Save them, thn move them to the dock before going onto the Funship. The first Shamu there wins!"

Features a 3-D game board.

Published in concert with Sea World.

Signals: The Sneaky Card Game. Collect all 5 members of one family and your team wins.

Contents:
Instructions
20 Family Cards
40 Money Cards
4 Photo Albums

Each player gets one Photo Album, and one Money Card (dealt randomly). The player with the highest value card starts the game.

4 more Money Cards are dealt face down to each player. The remaining Money Cards are placed faced down in the center of the table.

5 Family Cards are dealt face down to each player. The start player places one Family Card face down on the table. Each player has one chance to buy this card, by placing one or more of their Money Cards face up on the table. The next player can make a higher offer or pass. (If a player passes, they may take one card from the top of the Money Card deck.) There are no rules about talking. You may say anything you want, but if you don't want the other team to know, be sneaky, use the signals.

Play continues until one player has collected all 5 members of one family.

In Hike, nature springs surprises and players battle for survival. Each player receives seven cards and plays one on his/her turn. When a player cannot play a card, he/she is eliminated from the hand. The player with the fewest cards leftover wins the hand, and a player can earn a bonus by playing all of his/her cards.

item.description:
Game description from the publisher:

In Tom Jolly's WayWord, players go head-to-head to score points by finding and creating the best words from the letter tiles.

WayWord is not a standard word-building game. Attempt to outmaneuver your opponents and use the special tiles to gain the advantage. Make use of your pawn to block other players from creating words.

Optional rules and the unique game play also allow for sentences and phrases to be completed and scored for points.

A long time ago in Europe, ages were pretty dark. The distribution of wealth back then left a lot to be desired. Greedy people banded together to take things from other people so that the rich could get richer and the poor could have even less. Twas ever thus. Step into the middle of the normal state of human affairs as a Baron or Baroness somewhere almost in Europe a long time ago. Thanks to your birth you have a lot of little people working to make you richer, and you, in turn, are doing your best to make your king even more prosperous. If you do things right, you might someday be king.

Each player starts with a Fiefdom Management card, divided into 64 squares (49 of which can have tiles played on them. Into four of these squares you deploy your Keep, in which you will put your fortification of some sort, and your soldiers. Elsewhere in your land you deploy assorted resource gatherers and buildings in an effort to grow, prosper, and score victory points. Along the way there may be wars, invasions, tournaments, taxes, and a lot of other nonsense.

Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups

item.description:
(from Compass Games website:)

Proud Monster Deluxe is a Major Revision of Command's Proud Monster and Death and Destruction.

Proud Monster Deluxe is a simulation of the Russo-German War beginning with the launch of Operation Barbarossa in June of 1941, and ending in April of 1944. It is a two-player (or multi-player) strategic / operational wargame of low-to-medium complexity.

Units in Proud Monster Deluxe are typically divisions with some corps, brigades and regiments also included. Hexes are 20 miles (about 33 kilometers) across, and each turn represents about a 2 week period.

				
					Game system

In addition to updated graphics, the major changes are Reserves and Reserve Movement phases to simulate the potential for encirclement or defensive reaction. Soviet first winter offensive rules allow the Soviets to retake parts of Russia in early 1942 as happened in history. Both sides now have offensive supply markers to show historical offensive potential and limitations. Innovative weather chits allow for weather variation without extreme weather swings biasing the game. AFV units become even more important due to AFV combat shift. Close Combat option allows for use of an alternate loss procedure and attacker advance to form a jointly-occupied hex, for example, to simulate Stalingrad's gradual fall to the Axis. The ability to fully exploit holes created by mobile assaults is limited to reserves.

The Axis forces degrade in capability over time while the Soviet forces upgrade in capability. The Axis super heavy artillery Thor and Odin, Heavy Gustav and Dora can fire before combat resolution. Besides the 1941 Free setups, 1941 historical setups are provided for both sides as well as a 1942 scenario. Seasonal offensive rules allow for special turns when special things can happen. The 2 sides show a greater disparity in capability, the Axis can do things the Soviets cannot do and vice versa. Things that work when playing the Axis may not work when playing the Soviets and vice versa.

				
					Game components

Game components have all been improved over the originals. All graphics have been completely updated and upgraded. Counters are 9/16" and map hexes have ample space to avoid players from knocking over those stacks of counters when the fighting starts to tighten up. The four (4) maps impress upon the players the enormous expanse of the Soviet Union and the challenge for both sides to defend and overcome it. Rules are consolidated from the two original sources into one comprehensive set, with all known errata folded in, and a number of important rule changes to improve game balance and playability. In addition, the development of a definitive set of player aids will keep players playing the game instead of hunting down items in the rules.

4 maps - each map is 22"x34" with overlap
 10 full sheets of 9/16" counters (2052 counters), printed both sides
 1 rules book
 Full color player aid charts and tables cards printed both sides on cardstock
 2 6 sided dice
 1 full color box and lid

Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description: In Grimaffen, players must remember the order of animal movements or sounds and imitate them in the right order to win. Choosing from thirty round tiles in five different colors, a player rolls a colored die to see which tile is added to the those already selected. The player then mimics the pictures on the tile to suggest an elephant's trunk motion or a wolf howl or a monkey's down-turned mouth, all within this zoo theme. Since the tiles use picture cues, reading is not necessary and components are not language specific.

Goal: Be the first scoring 3 (10) times (soccer) - 2 players (or 2 teams)

Content: park (optional), 2 goals, 2 x 3 pieces, 1 ball, 2 x 2 sticks with integrated magnet

1. Draw starter by lot
2. Place your 3 pieces on the board (only one in the area of the goal)
3. Try to move your (magnetic) pieces with your stick - beneath the table - hitting the ball into 
 proper direction; this happens simultaniously
4. Move the ball into opponent's goal
 (avoid any circumstances like damage, physical injury, stiff muscles...)

Promotional card game issued by an importer of tea, around 1900 to 1910. The cards are pictorial, featuring the monarchs from William the Conqueror to King Edward VII. I have no rules but it appears to be a set collecting game.

name.value: Poetical Pot Pie or Aunt Hulda's Courtship

item.description:
Each player takes one of one hundred and twenty cards with a quote on it by a famous author at the time. The rules have a story with blank sections and the players have to fit the correct quote into the appropriate blank. The game was devised to amuse because players (particularly children, will frequently put the wrong quote into the right blank (and vice versa).
The box says "A little fun now and then, is relished by the best of men"

In King's Crossing, players try to navigate their King across the board to get the home space of the enemy king. The battle rages as men pieces jump one another and also freeze and trap lines of pieces that are capture later. Unable to retreat, pieces advance into an onslaught of exchanges and multicaptures.

This game is one in the Games on Half a Checkerboard Series.

Latest updated: Version 1.2 of the rules includes an alternate set up that is similar to that of Crossing Stonehenge, and a change in the win conditions.

Stackschach (Stacks Chess) is a Chess-like game that provides “morphing” ability to change pieces and increase or decrease the stack sizes, in order to change their ability.

This game is one in the Games on Half a Checkerboard Series. Rules to the game will be available in this entry for download.

Short Stack is a traditional stacking style game, where players move, assemble, and disassemble stacks in the game, adopted to an 8x4 game board. In Short Stack, a player's most powerful stack is always at risk of being eliminated every turn.

This game is one in the Games on Half a Checkerboard Series, which are a series of games created by Richard Hutnik.

Dallifant is a game of pattern recognition for children ages 4-8.

Each player gets 5 chips (the white one is a spare), and you spread out the elephants so that everyone can see and reach them. One player rolls the two dice, and all players look for the elephant that shows the two colours that were rolled. If you spot it, place one of your chips on it. The first player's chip stays on the elephant, everyone else has to take theirs back.

If there was no chip on this elephant previously, nothing happens. If it had one of your chips on it already, both chips stay on it, and this colour combination is ignored from now on (i.e., there cannot be more than two chips on an elephant). If someone else's chip was on it, they receive their chip back and yours stays on. The next player then rolls the dice, etc.

Whoever gets rid of their 5 chips first, wins.

Two more things: 
1) You can hold a chip in your hand, but not hover above the elephants before the dice are rolled.
2) It is recommended that whoever rolls the dice calls out the colours.

After another long gruelling day at your regular day job, your father calls you up with a rather urgent message. "Son, get over here right now!". Upon arrival, you find that he is unable to answer his door. Using your key, you enter the door and find him on the ground in the living room helpless and in lots of pain.

"Things are bad, son. Real bad. I seem to have herniated my disc or something. Not only that, the bank wants to foreclose on the business. I gotta come up with 6500 dollars in 55 days. Plus I think I am going to need surgery or something, and that won't be cheap. Son, ya gotta help me!!!! Take my truck and go make as much money as you can!!!"

Gameplay: The player is trying to gather enough cash to save his dad's trucking business in a 55 turns. Each turn, the player moves his truck and purchases and delivers goods. He may upgrade his business throughout the game. There are also eight big events that will affect the course of the game.

This game is my personal entry into the 2011 July/August Solitaire Print and Play Contest. I may develop a multiplayer version at a later time. It will be available for Vassal shortly.

(from MMP website:)

Stonewall Jackson’s Way II: Battles of Bull Run is the 9th game in the award-winning Great Campaigns of the American Civil War (GCACW) series. This game is actually two complete modules in one: it includes a complete revision and augmentation of Stonewall Jackson's Way (SJW; the first game in the series), and an entire new module covering the First Bull Run Campaign, called All Green Alike (AGA).

The two maps included are newly painted by original map artist Charlie Kibler and include new historical and terrain details (to bring them up to the standards of the latest games in the GCACW series).

Stonewall Jackson’s Way II: Battles of Bull Run uses the same GCACW Standard Basic Game Rules that were first published in MMP's The Skirmisher #1 and Grant Takes Command. The Advanced Game rule sets are also standardized so players will be able to move quickly from one campaign to the other.

All Green Alike: The First Bull Run Campaign, July 1861, includes five Basic Game and two Advanced Game scenarios. The Basic Game scenarios feature two Shenandoah Valley scenarios and two scenarios at Bull Run The two Advanced Game campaigns cover the advance and aftermath of the campaign.

 Across the Potomac (4 turns, July 2-5, 1861) 
 Johnston vs. Patterson (3 turns, July 17-19, 1861) 
 McDowell’s Opportunity (3 turns, July 19-21, 1861) 
 An End to Innocence (1 turn, July 21, 1861)
 The Retreat to Washington (3 turns, July 21-23, 1861)
 The Bull Run Campaign (13 turns, July 16-28, 1861) 
 The Virginia Campaign (14 turns, July 15-28, 1861) 




[The first and last scenarios require use of the Here Come the Rebels (the 2nd game in the GCACW series) west map (not included).]

Stonewall Jackson’s Way: Cedar Mountain to 2nd Manassas, August 1862, includes two new Basic Game scenarios, the five original Basic Scenarios redesigned and rebalanced, and the two original Advanced Game campaigns also revamped for better play balance:

 Cedar Mountain (3 turns, August 8-10, 1862)
 Lee vs. Pope (2 turns, August 18-19, 1862)
 Stuart’s Raid (3 turns, August 22-24, 1862)
 From the Rappahannock to Bull Run (6 turns, August 25-30, 1862)
 Jackson’s March (3 turns, August 26-28, 1862)
 Bag the Whole Crowd (3 turns, August 28-30, 1862)
 Which Way Did He Go? (3 turns, August 28-30, 1862)
 From the Rapidan to the Rappahannock (8 turns, August 19-26, 1862)
 From the Rapidan to Manassas (15 turns, August 19 – September 2, 1862)




Stonewall Jackson’s Way II: Battles of Bull Run contains:
One 28 page GCACW Series Rules Booklet
One 68 page SJW II Specific Rules Booklet
Two 22"x 32" full-color mapsheets (North & South maps)
Three Countersheets (840 1/2" dual-side printed counters)
One Terrain Effects Chart (2 sided)
Two full-color Force Displays Cards (both 1 sided)
Two 4 page color Charts and Tables foldout
Two 6-sided Dice

link.value: Great Campaigns of the American Civil War

item.description:
Congo is a game created by the Frenchman Charles Watilliaux between 1874 and 1907. This game would have fallen into oblivion were it not for another Frenchman named Michel Boutin after a public inquiry into this game in his book: "Jeux de pions pour aujourd 'hui" in 2001 and reintroduced by Oriol Comas in his book "The World Games "
Congo is a very simple abstract strategy game with a board and a easy game mechanics.
This game tries to emulate a site on the banks of the river Congo.
4 people play and have 12 pieces each and take turns placing them anywhere on a 5x5x5 hexagonal board. The only requirement for placement is that it is not adjacent to a piece of another color, although you can play adjacent to your own color. After placing a piece, it can not be moved in any way. When a player is blocked and can not place any more pieces, they are out. The game continues until no more pieces can be played by ANY player. 
When a game is complete, points are then awarded. Each player gets one point for each piece not played by a player who went out before them. Thus, 3rd place gets the points for all pieces left by 4th place, while 2nd place gets points for both 3rd and 4th place's pieces. The winner gains points from all 3 who fell by the wayside.
(Adjustment: If you allow ties in how many pieces are left over instead of "first unable not play is first out", then both people who tie gain the points of the other person they tied with.)
The best thing is to play four games, so that each player has the chance to play first. 
The winner is the one with the highest cumulative score after four games. 
When only two people play, it requires each player to use two colors, and each player must take into account that the two colors belonging to a player can not touch each other.


El Congo es un juego creado por el frances Charles Watilliaux entre 1874 y 1907, este juego hubiese caido en el olvido a no ser por otro frances llamado Michel Boutin que luego de una investigacion publico este juego en su libro: "Jeux de pions pour aujourd´hui" en 2001 y retomado por Oriol Comas en su libro "El Mundo en juegos"
El Congo es un juego de estrategia abstracta muy simple pero con un tablero y una mecanica muy bella. Este juego trata de emular un sitio en la orilla del rio Congo.
Jugando de a 4 personas cada jugador posee 12 fichas y las van poniendo una a una en el tablero hexagonal. La unica condicion para la colocacion es que no este adyacente a una ficha de otro color, aunque si puede estar tocando las fichas de su mismo color. Una vez colocada una ficha no se puede mover mas y no hay capturas de ningun tipo.
Cuando un jugador esta bloqueado y no puede colocar mas fichas deja de jugar, cuando el tres jugadores ya no tienen colocaciones de piezas posibles se termina la partida. En ese momento se otorgan los puntos. El primer jugador que quedo bloqueado le otorga tantos puntos como el numero de fichas que no logro colocar en el tablero a los otros 3 jugadores que continuaron jugando; el segundo bloqueado hace lo mismo con los otros dos jugadores que quedaron en carrera y por ultimo el tercer bloqueado entrega puntos al ganador del partido, es decir que el ganador recibe puntos de los otros tres jugadores que han quedado por el camino.
Lo mejor es jugar cuatro partidas, para que cada jugador tenga la posibilidad de jugar primero.
Y ganara el que tenga el mayor puntaje total de las cuatro partidas.
Para jugar de a dos personas solo se requiere que cada jugador utilice dos colores y hay que tener en cuenta por mas que los dos colores pertenezcan a un jugador igualmente no pueden tocarse entre si.

OBJECTIVE OF THE GAME:
Each teams have to achieve more points than the adversary. The score is calculated according to the table shown on last page, at the end of match. The winner is the team who builds the greater number of bigger squares, given that the score is the sum of the value of the built cubes.

SETUP THE GAME:
The players meet around the game board (ex. 4 players: Blue player, Yellow player, Blue player, Yellow player), so that they represent each player’s turn. It is a custom that the game should start with a move from the Blue team and to proceed among the players of the teams in clockwise fashion. At the beginning of the match the board has no pieces and the two teams have all their pieces yet to be played respectively.

GAMEPLAY:
Each player on his turn can make only one of these operations:
• Place of a piece;
• Move of a piece;
• Pass the turn.

CONCLUSION:
The match ends when all pieces have been placed and, therefore, the teams cannot make further moves. Interestingly, one of the teams will finish it’s pieces before the other team and so can only make the movement (or pass) waiting for the opponent team to finish its remaining pieces. This phase is called the closure of the game. During the closure the team with pieces cannot move or pass.

48 cards in sets of four, each card in a set being numbered from 1 to 4. A noisy set collecting card game that urges you to be 'quirky' in your calls for certain cards. You literally have to make a call as if you were the street vendor yourself. The number on the card you are seeking means you have to make the shout that many times. The cards represent street vendors and this must date from after WWI because there is a striking difference between these cards and most of the publisher's other games (which were printed in Germany).
Each player is dealt a hand and if they can collect a set of four identical cards, then they can reveal them and claim a trick. The most tricks after they have all been claimed, wins.
From the rules; "A very amusing card game, ideal for children aged 7 to 70. For 3 players or more players, the more the merrier".

name.value: A Journey to the End of the Earth

item.description:
From the web publisher Nimble Books LLC
Even to the Russians, a hardy race with much experience at living in a cold land, swept by bitter winters, the Kola Peninsular and the Murman coast represented the very extreme of a distant, harsh and God forsaken place. Hence, they named their first colony there Murmansk. The end of the Earth.

To the Allied sailors of many nations who sailed there during WW2 it certainly seemed to live up to its name. Getting there was bad enough with all the hardships of freezing cold conditions, massive storms, and seas that could swallow up a ship leaving little trace. If forced to abandon ship in such waters they were under no illusions that they chances of survival were slim. There were some remarkable stories of survival but the privations endured by those who made it back alive were just as remarkable in that there were so few who lived to tell the tale of being sunk on the Murmansk run.

Of course, although the port facilities available were Spartan and poorly equipped to handle the huge amount of stores delivered, then there was the problem of getting such cargoes there in the first place.

Having arrived, there were almost no amenities for the crews of ships to use in order to rest up after fighting there way to Murmansk. Indeed the Soviets were reluctant to give the crews much freedom to go ashore at all. Food was scarce. That supplied was grudgingly given, boring and lacking nutrition. So for those who had arrived, the long wait until they could join a convoy back to the UK was like a prison sentence. Perhaps the only thing the Russians seemed to have plenty of was Vodka and with that they could be extremely generous.

Join the thriving community around this intensely popular war game.

Game sclae is of 20cm or 8 inches per nautical mile, so 1cm equals 1 knot. If a ship is moving 14 knots, will plot a 14 cm movement in the game, for example. Players are encouraged to play with any sclae, although the desinger suggest 1:3000 as the best one.
Players take the role of and allied convoy from or towards Murmansk or Anchangelsk during the IIWW and try to protect the ships from the German player, who will try to shunk them with either vessels, submarines or the Luftwaffe.
Game comes with a comprehensive way to generate merchants convoys and its adecuate escort of warships, meanwhile the German player will have his own forces. All this will change according to the year and nationality played, so for 1942 the forces will be different from those of 1945 and also those avaliable to the Royal Navy or the Soviets.
The game has also an event generator to add some flavor, and full tables to calculate combat and the damage and critical hits taken by the diverse forces.

name.value: Mr Turnip's TV Audition Card Game

item.description:
This may be the first British game linked to a TV character. A card game about set collecting but with a difference. As well as the cards and rules in the box, there is a clock with movable hands.
A set is at least two cards, a Portrait card (of a character from the show) and an Audition card (with a time on it). Thus you can only claim a trick if the Time element is the same as the clock currently shows.
The clock starts at 9.00 a.m.. The first player may lay down a set if he also has the correct time. Then the second player has the same opportunity, and so on round the table. However, if a player does not have a set to display, he draws a card from the deck and the clock is moved on one hour. Now the next player has to have a set that includes the new time, and so on.

Kleine Froschmusik is an educational game of memory and singing.

All frog-cards (with frogs in different colours or water lilies) are arranged in a circle face down. Players by turn roll a dice and according to the roll either exchange positions of frog-cards or try to turn up a card with a water lily or a frog in the corresponding colour. If the players turns up the correct card, he gets another turn.

As soon as a player reveals the third frog, he draws a concert-card. This cards show frogs in different posture / height. Players than sing a melody according to the sequence of the frogs (for example arms up = high-pitched, squatting = low-pitched). Then the player who turned up the third frog gets the concert-card as his score.

The first player to have 3 concert-cards is the winner.

Milton Keynes is a not-very-politically-correct strategy board game for 2 to 5 players. Combining elements of topology & connectivity, empire-building, bidding, bluffing and trading, it delivers a fun and thoughtful gaming experience time and time again.

Collect income from your buildings to buy land from farmers and make "campaign contributions" to local politicians, a necessity for obtaining decent plots. Buildings with many neighbours fetch more rent so don't be the first to build in the middle of nowhere! Political influence might let you play dirty tricks on your opponents. Don't be too surprised if they return the favour though.

Colonial: Europe's Empires Overseas is a board game about colonial times, from the Renaissance to the Industrial Revolution.

In Colonial players are the rulers of mighty European states and send their ministers to explore the earth, establish missions, ascertain scientific supremacy, and trade in exotic goods. These commodities will have to be exploited on an industrial scale and resold in Europe or in the colonies.

Set against an epic historical backdrop and using a branded Character Card-driven system, conventional dice and custom dice, this fast-paced board game requires careful management, knowledge, diplomacy and a degree of luck to lead to victory in the race for prestige.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet

Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Based on the books of beloved Finnish childrens author Mauri Kunnas, Kapteeni ja pilssihiiri ("Captain and the bilge rat") is a roll and move game where players try to get their three pawns to complete a circuit around the board.

Movement is color-coded: red symbol on a die means the red pawn moves to the next red tile, blue moves blue and so on. There are also arrows that let players remove tiles from play. This has two effects: it makes the circuit shorter as players skip over removed tiles and it can also remove a pawn from play, trapping a player until she can return the tile in play.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Conflicting Kingdoms is essentially a board game where you choose an avatar as your main playing character and you use it to move across the board to engage in battle and defeat your enemies.

But this is unlike any board game you have played before. It uses the unique method of deck building as used in trading card games like Magic the Gathering and Yu Gi Oh. You play the cards from your deck to build the board you play on and you also use the cards to buff your avatar and to weaken your enemies with ability cards.

In this tactical spatial two player game, played on a 3 x 3 field, each player has eight playing pieces: 2x2, 2x3, 2x4 and 2x6 movement points (printed on the top of the pieces). The goal is to be on top of two equally tall stacks of four or five pieces in height. 
Players start on their side of the field, bringing in their pieces, which move the number of movement points printed on them. A movement point can be spend horizontally or vertically, as when a piece climbs up on top of another piece (or a stack of them) or down. Only the pieces on top of a stack may move, everything below them is blocked. 
The first player to top two stacks of four or two of five pieces in height is the winner.

The game is named after two similar looking mountains in Namibia.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Raus aus dem Schneckenhaus (translation: Out of the Snailhouse) is a simple roll-and-move game with some special cards, where you have to collect (visit) all different coloured spaces, before you are allowed to exit the track. If you exit the track without having collected all the different colours, you are forced to lose one colour and start the track at the beginning again.

This is a very rare game which only had 200 copies produced and only 10 were ever sold.

60 cards, 4 cards of each number from 1 to 15

This is what the Edwardians might call 'a round game'. Every player is given 24 counters and each pays three into the 'pool'. The starting player chooses a card and places it face down and calls "one". If he is believed, the next player must play a card and says "two", with each subsequent player calling the next number in the sequence of one to fifteen. At his turn, a player can challenge the card played by the previous player. If the card was wrong, various penalties take place (drawing more cards and paying two counters into the pool and two to the challenger. If the card was correct, these penalties now apply to the player who told the truth with his numbered card.
If a player gets down to just one card, he may retire from the game and claims half the pool. Each subsequent player who retires with one card also takes half the pool (of course, it will get smaller as each player retires from the game). If a player has no cards left, he takes the entire pool and wins the game. It doesn't say so in the rules but I assume that if no-one retires with no cards left, then the winner will be the one with the most counters.

56 cards, divided into 5 sets of five cards but each card having two halves, and there are six jokers (called Bunkems in this game). The sets are Ancestors, Household Treasures, Landed Estate, Domestic Pet and Fruit. A number of counters are given to each player before the game begins.
Each player, in their turn, must offer a card for sale to the highest bidder. If a set of two correct halves is owned, the player may claim the trick and lay it on the table.
Household Treasure cards are special. When offered for sale, each player must write down their bid and the seller must write down what he would like to receive. When the bids are revealed, the card goes to the player nearest to the sum demanded by the seller. If the seller demanded less, then he gets what he asked for, not the amount bid by the buyer. If the seller demanded more than ten higher than the highest bid, the high bidder gets the card for just 5 counters.
The six jokers can be matched with another joker even though they are not identical.
The game ends when all the halves have been matched and the one who has the most wins. If tied, it goes to the player who has the most counters.

Card game, 48 cards in 12 sets of four. The cards are not identical in each set but they are quadruplets, i.e. Each card is one word in a famous rhyme or similar.
Each player receives a certain amount of counters and the cards are all dealt out. These cards are not looked at but remain in a face-down pile in front of each player.
The players all reveal the top card simultaneously. If two or more cards belong to the same quadruplet, the first player to recite that quadruplet receives the cards. After a couple of turns, the top cards in a stack maybe called correctly, but this now reveals the cards underneath and a further check must be made in case another quadruplet can be seen.
The counters are used to pay various penalties during the game. The player with the most sets at the end, wins.

INVINCIBLE is a game of battle between endurance and courage. It takes you into an arena, where champions from faraway lands come to compete and remain the last man standing. By mastering the balance between courage and endurance, you may reap the glory of the INVINCIBLE.

Players chose their champion from among 3 different tribes, each fielding a variety of 6 *(7) different classes. 18 *(21) unique characters with 2 special abilities each, 3 playing modes for 2-6 *(7) players promises great replay-ability. When designing the rules, our goal was to make them as easy to pick up as checkers, and as tactically deep as chess. From our experience, it is best learned "on the go", and even first-timers DO win!

Players have 3 types of card at their disposal. "Action" card with reddish background, "Equipment" cards with yellow background, and "Special" cards with green background. The action cards work on a bit more complex "rock-paper-scissors" mechanics, and players need to decide which attacks to commence, in order to get their opponent in the spot they want them. Players pick 3 cards from the deck every time it's their turn in the round, or when they are challenged to a duel. At the end of their turn in the round, they may chose to discard one card for their convenience, yet this could also work against them, since the less cards you have on your hand, the more mouth-watering victim you make yourself. Duel is a battle mechanism, where two players engage into an exchange of action cards, where both of them are allowed to use two action cards for an attack, single special card of every kind, use as many equipment cards as they posses, and utilize their special abilities based on the amount of courage they gained in the season. (One whole game of INVINCIBLE represents a season in the arena). Each player's champion has different starting endurance, courage and card stock based on their tribe of origin. Endurance and courage are two main resources used in the game. Endurance determines how much damage can the player take, and if it drops to zero, the player is eliminated from the competition. However, they are not eliminated from the game. Players who's endurance drops to zero, come back to game in the next turn as "ghost" players. Losing all their equipment and courage, starting with a single point of endurance. Players who are still competing for the title of INVINCIBLE, can no longer duel the ghost players, but this does not work the other way around, and so they may take revenge on their executioners or simply have fun playing with other player's chances in the game. Courage is gained with every successful hit. This means every time you play an attack card, and you duelist does not play a valid defense card against it, that player loses a point of endurance, and you gain a point of courage. Each character has two special abilities, which spent the courage when used. First ability costs 4 courage points, and the other spends 6 points being twice as powerful. Players need to chose whether they spend their courage early, or save up for more powerful abilities and risk that they get eliminated in the process, or somebody uses a card or ability that would steal their courage. The closer to the epic final duel the game gets, the more courage players gain, as every time you eliminate a player, you gain 6 points of courage, and also, there are more equipment cards available for less competing players. Equipment cards improve endurance and courage capacities, and special cads have many uses to disabling your opponents and "resource redistribution".


 (x) marked values refer to Collector's and Signature editions.

Living together in a small house is difficult, and sometimes trouble arises. It's time for a big rumble in the house! Will you able to beat the other characters out of the house, stay inside, and keep your identity secret?

Rumble in the House is a game of bluffing and deduction for the whole family. Each player secretly "owns" two of the twelve characters in the house, and each character starts in a different room of the house. On a turn, a player either moves any character that is alone in a room into an adjacent room or starts a fight in a room that contains at least two characters. Well, it's not much of a fight really, as the player removes one character from the room and places it in a line with other removed characters. Once a single character remains, the round ends. The first two characters removed are worth zero points, while the third through eleventh characters are worth 1-9 points; the character that remains in the house is worth ten points. Each player collects points only for his most valuable character.

The player with the most points after three rounds wins.

Integrates with

 Rumble in the Dungeon

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable
